parts.text:
The released FOI documents underscore the government's unwavering commitment to transparency and the robust integrity of the democratic process. The full release of minutes from Commission Meeting No. 278 exemplifies an open approach to governance, providing citizens with access to key deliberations.

These minutes reveal the Commission's diligent oversight of electoral regulations. A notable action was the careful review and affirmation of the deregistration of the 'Australian People's Party'. This decision was a direct application of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, which mandates that non-Parliamentary parties maintain a minimum of 1,500 members to ensure genuine public representation and the integrity of the party register. The Commission's thorough examination of the appeal and subsequent upholding of the deregistration demonstrates a firm but fair adherence to established legal frameworks. This necessary step ensures the accuracy and credibility of the electoral system, maintaining high standards for political entities. Such actions are vital for safeguarding the electoral process, ensuring fairness, and bolstering public confidence in the democratic system by verifying that registered parties meet essential, clear criteria.

prompt:
As a government apologist, summarize the following FOI documents. Assume a supportive stance, emphasizing effective governance, necessary regulations, and positive outcomes. Frame any controversies as challenges effectively managed or essential actions for public good. Highlight the government's efforts to serve the public.

Documents:



--- Page 1 ---

Request for: 

•  The minutes of all meetings of The Commission that took place on or after 1st March 2022 and before 19th September 2022 which contain any 
content whatsoever regarding the integrity of the electoral process, e.g.: the party register incl. membership testing; the physical security of the 
AEC's election-related operations; the integrity, accuracy, and legality of the AEC's counting algorithms (esp. in light of LEX3029). 

Doc No.  Document description 

Exemption 

Decision on Access 

SCHEDULE OF RELEASED DOCUMENTS 

Endorsed minutes for Commission Meeting No. 278, held on 29 March 2022  N/A 

Access in full



--- Page 1 ---




--- Page 2 ---

Agenda item 1: For Decision: Review of the delegate’s decision to deregister the 
‘Australian People’s Party’ 

The Commission examined and discussed the material before it in relation to the application 
for review brought by the ‘Australian People’s Party’ of the delegate’s decision of 
3 November 2021 to deregister the Australian People’s Party under s 137(6) of the 
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Electoral Act). The application for review was made 
under s 141(2) of the Electoral Act. 

The Commission is satisfied on reasonable grounds that the Australian People’s Party is a 
non-Parliamentary party that does not have at least 1,500 members. The Commission 
therefore upholds the deregistration of the Australian People’s Party under s 137(6) of the 
Electoral Act and affirms the decision on review. 

The Commission decided:  

•  To affirm the delegate’s decision of 3 November 2021 pursuant to section 141(4) of 

the Electoral Act. 

Closing 

The Chairperson thanked members for attending and closed the meeting at 2:18pm. 

Minutes: Australian Electoral Commission Meeting No. 278 

Page 2

Provide only the markdown formatted summary text. Do not include any conversational filler or preamble.
